Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Luminescent Conducting Metallopolymers: Synthesis and Fundamental Studies Towards Optoelectronic Applications
Award.AbstractNarration: The Inorganic, Bioinorganic, and Organometallic Chemistry Program supports Professor Bradley Holliday of the University of Texas at Austin for the synthesis, characterization and reactivity of hybrid materials that incorporate luminescent metal complexes into polymer backbones. A cooperative relationship is obtained from the conductive polymers, which can readily shuttle charge, and the luminescent metal complexes, which offer the advantages of sharp emission properties (lanthanides), synthetic color tuning (iridium and platinum materials), and higher potential efficiencies. Dr. Holliday is involved in a research-based outreach program to local high school teachers and their students that allows both groups to participate in summer research. This outreach program also allows the participating teachers to have open access to synthetic equipment which can be borrowed and taken to their respective schools for use. This outreach activity leverages previous NSF funding in the Undergraduate Research Collaboratives (URC) Program by establishing a new Freshman Research Initiative research stream and supporting cyber-enabled instrument usage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was an early career research grant which helped a chemistry professor at the beginning of his independent research career to establish his research program, lend validation to some of his ideas, and to create education and outreach programs to better educate students across many different age groups. During the funding period, he was able to discover fundamentally new materials with important properties that have the potential to impact the fields of solid-state lighting, chemical catalysis, and electronics. These findings were reported to other scientists through several different outlets in order to maximize the impact of this work across the scientific community.

Many of the specific scientific goals of this project were directly met during the funding period. For example, the lanthanide (or rare earth) elements were successfully incorporated into a variety of novel materials to take advantage of their unique properties, such as their ability to emit light in the visible part of the spectrum. The fundamental scientific discoveries made over the course of this research project have the potential to lead to cheaper and more efficient lighting devices, such as OLED bulbs and electronic display screens. Additionally, other important fundamental scientific information was gained that could not have been anticipated at the beginning of this research endeavor.  For example, a new class of materials was discovered which can directly detect toxic heavy metals in water (i.e., lead ions). This research has the potential to lead to cheaper and easier ways to tell if drinking water is safe to consume.

This award has had many broader and less tangible benefits that equal, or exceed, the importance of the scientific discoveries. As mentioned above, this award helped to establish the independent research career of a young scientist who will go on to train many other students who wish to pursue a scientific education. In the funding period alone, this award supported the educational goals of over 50 researchers and educators ranging from high school students to graduate students to high school educators. Moreover, this award has led directly to more than 10 advanced degrees being earned in the area of materials chemistry. These outcomes will have the widest impact as these young scientists are now poised to have a direct positive bearing on the economic, technological, and educational future of our country.
